text: I discovered <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Tokenize.jl|Tokenize.jl> today. I am a bit ignorant so could someone explain to my why one would want to perform lexical analysis on raw Julia code? What would be the rationale for doing such analysis?

elements.text: today. I am a bit ignorant so could someone explain to my why one would want to perform lexical analysis on raw Julia code? What would be the rationale for doing such analysis?

text: short asnwer: a lot of reasons and use case

elements.text: short asnwer: a lot of reasons and use case

text: It's the used for CSTParser.jl and also used by eg OhMyREPL for syntax highlighting.

elements.text: It's the used for CSTParser.jl and also used by eg OhMyREPL for syntax highlighting.

text:
idk if this is the point of confusion but:
the processing of both natural languages and programming language have a lexing or tokening step early in the processing where the stream of characters is broken up into tokens or words.

The next step traditionally is to construct a tree (or some other structure) out of those tokens. This step is called parsing.
Its a bit out of fashion for natural languages (where the modern fashion is to just dump steams of tokens int RNNs).
But its pretty standard for programming languages.

Sometimes people use the word parsing to cover both tokenizing and building trees  (/other structures)
